Award.AwardTitle: Alkane Activation at Catalytic Metal Surfaces: A Coupled Experimental and Theoretical Study of Reaction Dynamics and Energy Transfer at the Gas-Surface Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division supports Professor Ian Harrison, University of Virginia, for studies of Alkane Activation at Catalytic Metal Surfaces: A Coupled Experimental and Theoretical Study of Reaction Dynamics and Energy Transfer at the Gas-Surface Interface. A heated effusive molecular beam doser will be used to impinge C1-C9 alkane molecules at variable gas temperature onto a surface such that activation barriers for dissociative chemisorption can be surmounted. Dissociative sticking coefficients will be measured and the multidimensional experimental data will be used to test and develop theoretical models of gas-surface reactivity. Using the combination of the effusive molecular beam results to be measured here, existing supersonic molecular beam dissociative sticking measurements, electronic structure theory calculations, and kinetic modeling the effects of molecular rotation, vibrational efficacy, alkane complexity, surface structure, gas and surface temperatures, early/late transition state barrier position, and gas-surface energy transfer on dissociative sticking will be addressed.

This research will experimentally characterize and theoretically model the activation of C1-C9 alkanes at catalytic metal surfaces. The research will be directed towards gaining a molecular-level understanding of the activated dissociation of alkanes at surfaces, which is oftentimes believed to be the rate limiting step in the catalytic transformations of alkanes into more valuable chemicals such as hydrogen, synthesis gas, alkenes, or fuels. Alkanes are a targeted product of biomass reforming and more energy efficient and selective catalysis of alkanes is desirable in the quest to efficiently convert renewable biomass to fuels. Importantly, a diverse group of young graduate and undergraduate students will be educated in the interdisciplinary fields of surface science, catalysis, and reaction dynamics through coupled experimental and theoretical work on basic science relevant to a key societal goal, namely, engineering a sustainable energy future. Minority undergraduates will be taught and hosted as part of a summer science encouragement program at the University of Virginia whereby students will learn about renewable energy research. Graduate students will be encouraged and continue in their outreach laboratory demonstrations at local elementary schools.

POR.DRECONTENT: Research was directed towards gaining an improved understanding and quantitative modeling of the activated dissociation of alkanes at catalytic metal surfaces. This process of dissociative chemisorption is generally believed to be the rate limiting step in the catalytic transformations of alkanes into more valuable chemicals such as hydrogen, synthesis gas, alkenes, or fuels. Improving these transformations is desirable because methane and other light alkanes are the principal components of natural gas, which fracking technologies have made relatively inexpensive in the United States. New effusive molecular beam techniques were developed to make measurements of alkane dissociative sticking coefficients, S(Tg, Ts, J), as a function of gas temperature, surface temperature, and molecular angle of incidence on the surface. The multidimensional experimental measurements produced were used  to test and advance quantitative theoretical models of gas-surface reactivity and energy transfer. Accomplishments relevant to intellectual merit have been to (i) establish that for activated dissociative chemisorption of methane on a Pt(111) metal surface, molecular rotations and translations parallel to the surface are spectator degrees of freedom, molecular vibrational energy is, on average, only 40% as efficacious in promoting reaction as is molecular translational energy directed along the surface normal, and surface phonons supply the majority of the energy required to surmount the activation barrier to dissociative chemisorption under the thermal equilibrium conditions relevant to catalysis. (ii) incorporate quantum mechanical tunneling into our precursor mediated microcanonical trapping (PMMT) models of activated dissociative chemisorption, and demonstrate that tunneling is typically negligible at temperatures relevant to industrial catalysis; (iii) develop a dynamically-biased (d)-PMMT model which quantitatively replicates, with unprecedented accuracy, the experimental H2(D2) dissociative chemisorption/associative desorption dynamics on Cu(111), including the surface temperature dependence for the first time; (iv) provide quantitative means to evaluate the impact of dynamics on gas-surface reactivity for reactions modeled by the d-PMMT where dynamical constraints can be set to their statistical values for comparative purposes (e.g., dynamics reduce by 100-fold the thermal reactivity of H2/Cu(111) at catalytic temperatures - a significant effect equivalent to an increase in activation energy of ~27 kJ/mol); (v) begin density functional theory (DFT) electronic structure calculations using the Vienna ab initio software package (VASP) to define transition state properties and frequencies to reduce parameterization in PMMT models of activated dissociative chemisorption; (vi) find correlations between DFT-calculated transition state properties and experimentally extracted d-PMMT model transition state parameters for methane dissociative chemisorption that may enable all in silico model development;
